bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Wickliffe Rose, July 26, 1921

div1.p: [Carter] warns that mosquito control will be harder in Peru because the local officials are unfamiliar with quarantine procedures.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Wickliffe Rose, July 26, 1921
div1.opener:
File
New Glasgow P. O.,
Amherst County, Va.,
July 26, 1921
Dr. Wickliffe Rose, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
Referring to your last paragraph, I have at present no sug-
gestions to offer.

I would have had as regards Peru were White not down there,
but it is wiser to await his reports and advice.

One thing I think you will have to be prepared for: It will
be difficult--if not impossible--to continue Stegomyia control in
Peru for a year after the last reported case of yellow fever. The
people differ from those in Guayaquil (1) They have not suffered the
commercial loss and inconvenience of years of quaratine: (2) They are
much more conceited and unwilling to take advice: (3) and more short-
sighted--looking only to the immediate present--than are the
Guayaquilenos. They are also selfish. There are few towns--I fear
few--people--in Peru, which would not rather imperil the whole
country than suffer any considerable inconvenience. A people hard to
work with, and the autho4ities--local political and Central Sanitary--
were, last year, no better than the people.

Fortunately this continuation of Stegomyia control here
seems less necessary than in Central America.

The point of first importance is the protection of Guayaquil.
I would count the re-infection of this place a graver thing than further
spread of fever in Peru. South of Trujillo we could probably--not
certainly--depend on its spontaneous elimination after a epidemic of
two or three years, as formerly--in '81-'83, I believe. It might re-
quire assistance at the end of that time by Stegomyia control. For
Guayaquil spontaneous elimination could not be hoped for. Of course,
the elimination of the fever in Peru would make Guayaquil safe from
that source, and even its control--i. e. diminution--is an important
measure of protection to Guayaquil. Fortunately there is none in the
Departments of Piura or Tumbez whence the threat would be, and was,
much greater than from the further South.

I presume it will take some time for the training of the bachterio-
logists by Noguchi--6 to 12 months? And this will I judge determine the data of
the African expiditions.

I am enclosing a letter and paper received from Hanson the
last mail. He will succeed in the elimination of fever this year,
unless it has already passed south of the Desert of Viru. If it has,
that is another story and a change of method may be indicated.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, New Glasgow P. O.,
Amherst County, Va.
“Geddes/”
